Find out about our 12-year journey to build Britain’s missing museum, our exciting plans for our permanent home, and discover some of the rich migration histories that surround the site.

name: Sitopia Farm
description: Sitopia Farm is a 2-acre organic and regenerative farm in the London Borough of Greenwich. We are on a mission to improve the food system. We grow vegetables and flowers and sell direct to our local community, to chefs, and to florists. Through our farming and events, courses and community volunteering, we reconnect people to the soil, the joy of good food and flowers, and to each other.

name: Skyline Soundscape at The Valley Room, AiR
description: The Valley Room is a research and project space created by AiR. It considers artist-making in the Lea Valley through a gathering of artefacts, films, objects, maps, books. Monthly openings highlight one artwork, with the artist making an intervention or exhibition.
address: Unit A29 Hastingwood Trading Estate, N18 3HU

name: Soho Photography Quarter
description: Architect led tour of the new Soho Photography Quarter and The Photographers’ Gallery's refurbished ground floor, which has been redesigned to connect to this new public space that features a 45m ‘Artfrieze’ at the core of a curated public art programme. The event will feature an introduction to Sian Davey’s 'The Garden' by curator Eva Eicker.

name: South East London Community Energy - Walking Tour
description: Join South East London Community Energy for a walking tour of two community energy sites and a workshop on how community energy can help future-proof our city.
address: Deptford station, Deptford High Street, SE8 3NU

name: Southall Manor House
description: Southall Manor House is a Grade II* Listed Tudor building - the oldest building in Southall and potentially one of the oldest surviving buildings in West London. The building underwent recent refurbishment, extension and landscaping from 00 Architects. For Open House, the building's heritage will be animated by scents from perfumers 420Tuesdays and Kushbu.
address: Southall Manor House, The Green, Southall, UB2 4BJ

name: Southwark Heritage Centre and Walworth Library
description: This multi-use community space provides a combined library and heritage service. Visitors will enjoy unique access to the borough’s historic collections alongside a state-of-the-art library with a range of meeting and study spaces.

name: St Alphege Church, Edmonton
description: The Church of St Alphege is Grade II listed, combining modernist Scandinavian and traditional ecclesiastical forms with good-quality sculptural enrichment; graceful, lofty interiors, with subtle detailing applied consistently throughout.
address: Rossdale Drive/Hertford Road, Lower Edmonton, N9 7LG

name: St Andrew's Kingsbury (new church)
description: Meticulous 1930s rebuilding (complete with original furnishings) of an 1840s Marylebone church. Grade I listed. Contains works by Pugin, Burges, Street, Pearson and Butterfield.
address: junction of Church Lane/Tudor Gardens/ Old Church Lane, Kingsbury

name: St Anne's Church, Kew Green
description: St Anne's Church, Kew Green was consecrated in 1714. Built with the support of Queen Anne it has been a place of worship for the Royal Families over the centuries. The original 'chapel' has been extended many times and the church is now a little known gem in South West London with a fascinating past.

name: St Anne's Church, Limehouse
description: St Anne's Limehouse has been described as 'the finest parish church in England.' Designed by Nicholas Hawksmoor, it is Grade I listed and one of the Major Churches in the Church of England. It is home to a thriving Christian congregation.

name: St Augustine's Church
description: St. Augustine's, Kilburn affectionately known as 'The Cathedral of North London' was established in 1870. Fr. Kirkpatrick, the first Vicar, engaged John Loughborough Pearson as the architect with the result being what many consider one of his finest works. Externally in 1890 with the tower and spire it became the 2nd tallest building in London (now ecclesiastically 2nd to St. Paul's Cathedral).

name: St Barnabas Church
description: Early English style, full of Pre-Raphaelite decoration. Important works by Bodley, Comper and Cundy and windows by Kempe and Tower. First Oxford Movement church. Recently restored 10 bell peal

name: St Bartholomew's Hospital
description: The Grade I listed North Wing at St Bartholomew’s Hospital in the City of London houses two of England’s most important interiors, the Great Hall, and the Hogarth Stair with its large paintings by William Hogarth. The hospital was designed by architect James Gibbs and construction of the North Wing was completed in 1732.
address: St Bartholomew's Hospital, West Smithfield, EC1A 7BE

name: St Bonifatius RC German Church
description: Centre of German religious and cultural life for more than 200 years. Impressive 20th century church building with contributions from various German artists. Exhibition of German émigré artist Hans Feibusch "Five Stories from the Old Testament" (courtesy of Ben Uri Gallery). Demonstration of the organ by resident organist Paul Dichtl.

name: St Bride's Church, Fleet Street
description: Wren designed building of 1675, interior lost in blitz of 1940, reopened 1957 with 'Wren inspired' interior
address: St Bride's Church, St Bride's Avenue, EC4Y 8AU

name: St Giles Parish Church, Camberwell
description: A large Grade II* listed parish church - one of Scott's finest designs. Key features include the magnificent east window by Ruskin. Interior recently redecorated and restored together with recently restored spire.

name: St James's Piccadilly
description: St James's Piccadilly is a Grade I listed Christopher Wren church in the heart of the West End. Completed in 1684, and known as the Artists' Church, its interiors include historic works of art by Grinling Gibbons (reredos, organ case and font), postwar Classical interiors by Albert Richardson, and contemporary art by Che Lovelace honouring the 18th-century abolitionist Quobna Ottobah Cugoano.

name: St Lawrence Jewry
description:
First built in c.1136, St. Lawrence Jewry was destroyed in the Great Fire of 1666. The present church was designed by Sir Christopher Wren in 1671. The interiors were destroyed in December 1940 during the World War Two and restored in 1957, faithful to Wren’s original design. Extensive conservation works were completed in 2023.
The official church to the City of London Corporation.

name: St Luke Woodside
description:
St Luke Woodside is a large, airy late Victorian church.
The fittings and art added over the 20th and into the 21st century tell the history of the Church of England in this part of London.
address: St. Lukes Church, Portland Road, SE25 4RB

name: St Margaret Pattens Guild Church
description: Take a guided tour of a beautiful example of a Wren church with unique features

name: St Margaret's Church, Lee
description:
The Church was built in 1839/41 as a white 'Hall-Church'. 
The 1870s Gothic Revivalism was overseen to a very high standard, by James Brooks and helped by 10 top craftsmen of the day. We also have a WWI Memorial by Violet Pinwill.
address: St Margarets Church,  Lee Terrace, SE13 5DN

name: St Mark's Church, Biggin Hill
description:
The Moving Church.
On his appointment to Biggin Hill in 1951, Rev Vivian Symons had the vision to bring the materials for a new church building from the disused All Saints, North Peckham. But first, he had to deconstruct a huge Victorian church, and bring it by himself to its new site.
However, St Mark's is Grade 2 listed, not because of its origin, but due to its style.
address: St Mark's Church, 10 Church Road, Biggin Hill, TN16 3LB

name: St Marks Schoolhouse
description: Dow Jones Architects has recently refurbished this 1866 listed schoolhouse as their architecture studio. The project has created a light-filled contemporary work space, and demonstrates a sensitive, low carbon approach to an historic restoration.
address: St Marks Schoolhouse, Battersea Rise, SW11 1EJ

name: St Mary Aldermary
description: The church was first mentioned c1080 and is the oldest of the City churches dedicated to St Mary. It became a Guild Church by virtue of the  City of London (Guild Churches) Act, 1952.  It is the only Wren church built in the Late Gothic style after the Great Fire of London, 1666, thanks to a bequest.

name: St Mary Magdalene Church
description: Fine Victorian Gothic church with impressive windows and painted chancel. Paintings by Buckeridge and Westlake 1897. Restoration of chancel paintings was to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II. (2012)

name: St Mary Magdalene Church & Nature Reserve
description: Grade I listed 12C church, with London's largest churchyard and one of the best-preserved Norman archways in the country, as well as other interesting features, including an anchorite's cell and 750-year-old wall paintings.
address: St Mary Magdalene Church, High Street South, E6 3PG

name: St Mary The Virgin Wanstead
description: One of the finest examples of Georgian architecture. It has been hardly altered since built. The church is a rectangular building of Portland stone, with a projecting chancel. Two external walls were restored in 2019. Grade I listed
address: St Mary The Virgin Church , Overton Drive, E11 2LW

name: St Mary the Virgin Church
description: A church with 850 years of history to explore. Records show that the church's first Rector arrived in around 1175. By about 1200, a nave, a short chancel, and the lower two-thirds of the west tower had been built.; the top third of the tower was in place by 1400.  The building was enlarged to designs by George Gilbert Scott (north aisle, 1856) and John Oldrid Scott (south aisle, 1879).

name: St Mary's Convent
description: Convent in 18C Grade II listed house, c1764-1792, with original features including fine decorative plasterwork. Various additions including west wing (1913-15), and harmonious care home facilities and chapel by PRP Architects (1998-2001).

name: St Michael Cornhill
description: A church building has occupied this site for at least a thousand years.  Destroyed in the Great Fire of 1666, but rebuilt in the 1670s. Known as a Wren church, the architect was Nicholas Young.
address: St. Michael's Cornhill, St. Michael's Alley, EC3V 9DS

name: St Michael and All Angels Church
description: James Maltby Bignall (1827-1885) worked in the practice of Sir George Gilbert Scott, the architect of St Pancras Station. The style of St Michael's is late Gothic Revival, in its size and height reminiscent of Northern European churches.

name: St Nicholas Church
description: Built in the Gothic style with dressed flint and stone dressings. There are monuments to Joseph Glover (1628), Lady Dorothy Brownlow (1699), William Earl Talbot (1782) and Isaac Littlebury (1740). The churchyard has 5 Grade II tombs.

name: St Pancras Waterpoint
description: At around 9m x 6m and 3-storeys high, the top floor originally contained a vast 70 cubic metre capacity cast iron water tank. This tank now forms an impressive viewing gallery; the exterior has ornate brickwork and elaborate detailing.
address: St Pancras Cruising Club, Camley Street, N1C 4PN

name: St Patrick's Church
description: Built thanks to a generous gift from local benefactress, Mrs Lavinia Keene, St Patrick's was consecrated in July 1940 and is unusual in style. The concrete and brick interior contrasts with the dramatic, colourful reredos. Grade II listed.

name: St Paul's Bow Common
description: Described as 'the most significant church built after the WWII in Britain' - Brutalist, inclusive and influential signpost for future church design.
address: Corner of Burdett Road/ St Paul's Way, E3 4AR

name: St Paul's Steiner School
description: Grade II* listed old church building designed by Sir Charles Barry, 1826 built as one of the million churches scheme. Redundant in 1980's then rebuilt with st pauls steiner occupancy from 1993 and now a full school since 1995, which steiner architechtural influence and the gothic style original, pews turned into classrooms mainly by volunteers and workshops to gain experience. Still unfinished.
address: St. Pauls Steiner School, 1 St. Pauls Road, N1 2QH

name: St Paul's, Newington
description: Modern architecture church with large copper and lead roof and concrete, brick and stained glass external structure. Marble, wood and plaster interior and artwork by Sculptor Freda Pinto and Gerald Holtom.

name: St Vedast alias Foster
description: 12C church. During the Great Fire of 1666 the church building escaped total destruction, and was restored. Christopher Wren was eventually called in to rebuild St Vedast, completing the work in October 1673.

name: Swakeleys Estate
description: A most important house in Ickenham an outstanding example of Jacobean architecture built in the 1630s. Red brick construction laid in English bond on an H plan. Great Hall includes the 1655 Harrington Screen, 18C marble fireplace panelling.
address: Swakeleys Road, Ickenham (access from Milton Road) , UB10 8LD

name: Swiss Cottage Library
description: Grade II listed building by renowned Modernist which has been refurbished and remodelled whilst protecting the building's landmark status.

name: Switchboard Studios
description: Built in the 1950s, this site was originally the head offices for a large consortium of industrial spaces which produced dyes and food colourings. It is now a creative workspace with 26 studios for creative businesses and an event space.
address: Switchboard Studios,, 50 Uplands Business Park, E17 5QJ

name: T J Boulting
description: Red brick and Portland stone corner building with three prominent signs in Arts & Crafts style lettering in green and gold mosaic for the company 'TJ Boulting & Sons'.

name: Taylor & Chatto Courts and Wilmott Court, Frampton Park Estate
description: Taylor Court and Chatto Court, together with Wilmott Court, form a pair of award-winning mixed-tenure housing, accommodating 45 new homes and commissioned by the Hackney Council on two sites at the edge of the post-war Frampton Park Estate.

name: Temple Bar
description: Temple Bar is a 350 year old gateway to the City of London, designed by Sir Christopher Wren. It formerly stood in Fleet Street, and is the last surviving gateway to the City of London. This beautiful structure has a fascinating history, which will be revealed to visitors.
address: First Floor, Paternoster Lodge, 2 Paternoster Square, EC4M 7DX

name: The Africa Centre
description: A 1960s former office block that has been transformed into a vibrant cultural hub showcasing the best of contemporary African culture and heritage. This project is supported by the Mayor of London.

name: The Barbican & The City Gardens
description: The Barbican is a residential complex of around 2,000 flats, maisonettes, and houses in the City of London. Built on the site destroyed by The Blitz during the World War II, The Barbican Estate is a fascinating development and an icon of Brutalist architecture. Architects were Chamberlain, Powell and Bon. You will find an oasis in the middle of buildings, with gardens and water features.

name: The Black Horse
description: Join us for an exclusive architect and designer led tour of The Black Horse Bar & Pizzeria. Hear directly from the architect and interior designer from Pencil & Brick and Flamingo & Oak about their inspiration and creative process behind designing this award-nominated venue. Discover the design elements that make The Black Horse unique and gain insights into their work.
address: The Black Horse, 1 Wickford Way, E17 6ZH

name: The Blue Market  Bermondsey
description:
Made in Bermondsey Tour
GUIDED TOUR/ 14:30 - 15:30
BOOKING REQUIRED 

Join the people behind the Made in Bermondsey project for a tour to discover the historic links interwoven into the design work. 

Made In Bermondsey is a historic market place and high street regeneration project by Hayatsu Architects and Assemble completed in 2022
address: Big Local Works, 4 Market Place, SE16 3UQ

name: The Broadgate Tower
description: A rare opportunity to gain insight into the workings of this globally renowned architecture, engineering and urban planning practice, based in an iconic SOM-designed building.

name: The Brunel Museum
description: London's story of an engineering family that changed the world. Dramatic new staircase below sculpture garden leads to underground chamber. Travel by train through first underwater shopping arcade & fairground to view Thames Tunnel portico.

name: The Butcher, The Baker and The Candlestick Maker
description: Trade and craft associations have flourished for many centuries. The City of London companies, now collectively known as the Livery, are unique in their survival, number and diversity. The social and economic conditions which gave birth to the original guilds have long since been overtaken by the development of industry and commerce, but the livery companies still flourish today.

name: The Corner House
description:
Designed by Langstaff Day Architects, The Corner House is a self-build, low energy sustainable CLT home on a constrained brownfield site in Stoke Newington overlooking Butterfield Green.
This is a sneak preview, with the home competing in the next few weeks…

name: The Department Store
description: The Department Store is an award winning refurbishment of a dilapidated Edwardian building in Brixton, completed by Squire and Partners in 2017. The design was informed by the layers of history and existing fabric of the heritage building.
address: The Department Store, 248 Ferndale Road, SW9 8FR

name: The Earls Court Development Company
description: Learn about our plans to transform this 40-acre site into a new piece of the city that is inclusive, climate resilient and brimming with opportunity, and sustainability underpinning the masterplan. A destination to discover wonder, a home for creative talent and a showcase for one of the fastest growing industries in the world - clean and climate tech.
address: Earls Court Project Rooms, 16-18 Empress Place, SW6 1TT

name: The Fleet beneath your feet
description: A walk along and around a stretch of London's most famous hidden river. The River Fleet is underground these days, but it's left its mark on the landscape. Discover the layers of history in this less explored corner of central London.

name: The Gilbert & George Centre
description: The Gilbert & George Centre was originally established as a registered charity by the artist in 2009 with the objective to advance the education of the public in the arts, and generally to advance the arts, architecture, heritage and culture for the benefit of the public.

name: The Great Fire of London
description:
In 1666, the conflagration devastated most of the City, thousands of houses, many churches and St Paul's Cathedral destroyed. Christopher Wren played a major role in rebuilding the City. 
Free walks led by City of London Guides

name: The Hospital Chapel of St Mary & St Thomas
description: Founded c1145 by the Abbess of Barking as a hospice for thirteen old and infirm men, the present building is 12C and 19C. Grade II* listed with many interesting monuments, including Burne-Jones windows.

name: The Isokon Collection and Open Workshop
description: Come and explore the Isokon collection and workshop and learn more about our manufacturing processes. Experience the techniques and materials that are used to craft our collection which spans over 90 years of modernist and contemporary furniture design.
address: Isokon Workshop, Unit 2B (rear section), Uplands B Business Park

name: The John Morden Centre and Morden College Almshouses
description:
Morden College is a charity dedicated to supporting older people, founded in 1695 by the pioneering merchant, Sir John Morden.

The original 1695 Grade I listed Quadrangle by Edward Strong, Sir Christopher Wren's master stonemason, has provided older people with accommodation for over 300 years. Across the site and beautiful grounds, the John Morden Centre, a new community space, won the RIBA Stirling prize in 2023.
address: Morden College, 19 St Germans Place, SE3 0PW

name: The Lesnes Estate - And the campaign to save it
description: The Lesnes Estate, part of the Thamesmead 'town of tomorrow', is at threat of demolition, resulting in the dispossession of the diverse and vibrant working-class community that call the estate their home. Join housing campaigners and residents to celebrate the estate, go on tours of the area, and hear from speakers about the process of estate regeneration, and its impact on communities.

name: The Link Up
description:
This is your invite to The Linkup! A space where young POC and those from working-class communities can connect, create and speak your truth.

At The Linkup, we'll dive into real conversations and create a collaborative mural that captures our experiences, our cultures and our vision for the future in London. This is your space to express, explore and inspire.

name: The London Centre
description: Home of NLA, London’s built environment community, and located in the West Wing of the Guildhall complex, the Centre highlights 3 scale architectural models of London: the New London Model, the City Model and the Royal Docks Model.

name: The Marshall Building - London School of Economics and Political Science
description: A large multi-purpose building occupying a pivotal position at the southern corner of Lincoln’s Inn Fields.  The building provides state of the art, flexible teaching spaces on the lower levels and faculty accommodation on the upper levels.
address: The Marshall Building, 44 Lincoln's Inn Fields, WC2A 3PF

name: The Paper Garden
description: This summer Jan Kattein Architects complete one of the most ambitious circular economy buildings attempted in the UK in decades. The 300m2 educational building  in Canada Water forms part of the Paper Garden, for charity Global Generation.

name: The Pinehouse Parasite
description: We are delighted to present this spectacular extension and refurbishment project in Wanstead. The new side infill extension has a faceted geometry with a roof that rises up to meet a skylight at its highest point. An expanded bronze anodised mesh wraps around the existing building like a parasite. This fascinating geometry is achieved using a timber frame construction.

name: The Questors Theatre
description: Originally planned in 1954, the first new theatre after the war, the Questors Playhouse opened in 1964, by which time its design had been followed by the Chichester Festival Theatre and the Crucible, Sheffield.
address: The Questors Theatre, 12 Mattock Lane, W5 5BQ

name: The Soho Poly
description: From 1972 to 1990, the Soho Poly was one of London’s leading alternative theatre venues - dedicated to widening access to the arts and frequently giving voice to underrepresented playwrights, actors and directors.
address: University of Westminster, 16 Riding House St, W1W 7DT

name: The Stanley Picker Trust, Picker House
description:
Completed in 1968 by Kenneth Wood, the house is an untouched time capsule of 1960s colour, innovation and design, with interiors  provided by the Conran Group. 

Situated in a quiet cul-de-sac on steeply sloping ground, the location was both an inspiration and a challenge for Ken Wood when creating the modern split-level design. The garden and pavilion gallery are also included in the tour.

name: The Tin Tabernacle / Cambridge Hall
description: Constructed in 1863, Kilburn’s grade II corrugated Iron Church set about it’s new course in the 1950's when it’s interior was transformed to resemble naval training ship (TS) Bicester.

name: The Trampery Wood Green
description:
The Trampery Wood Green is host to 50 artists currently occupying studios in the building. At our open day event you will have the opportunity to come and see their work and their workspaces!
As part of the open day we will activate the space by hosting multiple activities in the lounge throughout the event. For this we are planning on having an agenda of skill-sharing, music and food and drinks.

name: The Triangle Artist Open Studios
description: Come and discover work by some of the UK’s top artists – from internationally acclaimed names to new and emerging talent. See behind the scenes of a working studio, meet artists, photographers, designers, illustrators and all sorts of creative people face to face and buy works of art directly from their studio.

name: Thornhill Square
description: A tour of one of the largest and best preserved early Victorian squares and gardens in London, also with a magnificent and original public library of 1906, which shows Byzantine and Art Nouveau influences, and a remarkable Gothic church. Refreshments available.
address: Main door of St Andrew’s Church, Bridgeman Road, N1 1BQ

name: Throwley Yard Cinema
description: Hello! We're Throwley Yard Cinema, Sutton's independent cinema and cultural hub. With a strong focus on the local community, our four cinema screens are only part of a wider offering which also includes a café, bar, live events, DJ academy, socialising and much more.

name: Timber Wharf Artist Open Studios
description: A chance to see behind the scenes of working artists' studios, this SPACE building is home to glass and lighting makers, ceramicists, fine artists and the London Embroidery Studio.

name: Tin House
description: Making efficient use of an irregular urban site, this house is made up of interconnecting top-lit pavilions arranged to define a tranquil private courtyard.

name: Tooting Bec Lido
description: Outdoor pool 100x33 yards. One million gallons of unheated water. Iconic outdoor cubicle doors, fountain and café added in the 1930s, with Art Deco style entrance in 2001. Sports hall pavilion added in 2016.
address: Tooting Bec Lido, Tooting Bec Road, SW16 1RU

name: Tottenham Hale & placemaking together
description: We're running guided walks in Tottenham Hale showcasing Haringey's new council homes and the council's commitment to working with residents on place-making and regeneration as part of our Haringey Deal. The walks start/end at Living Under One Sun in Down Lane Park, where there will be a display about our programme to build 3,000 new council homes by 2031 and our regeneration of Down Lane Park.
address: Living Under One Sun Community Cafe and Hub

name: Tottenham Tales Walk
description: Join us on a guided walk following the  'Tottenham Tales' trail. Tottenham has a rich and fascinating tapestry of tales of local rebels, artists, pioneers and more. The tour will take us around South Tottenham, a treasure hunt for the new Tottenham Tale signage that highlights the buildings and sites that hold remnants of these tales, supported by an online map to bring archive material to life.
address: Outside Seven Sisters Station, 231-243 High Rd, N15 5BT

name: Tour the Square Root Factory
description: Square Root Soda will be running live production shifts to demonstrate how our drinks get made. You will be shown around our production space, where fruit will be being juiced and our other ingredients processed into our soda mix. Then you will be taken around our state-of-the-art packaging line. You will leave with an understanding of what the inner workings of a factory look like.
address: Unit D11, Leyton Industrial Village, Argall Avenue, E10 7QP

name: Tower Hamlets Town Hall
description:
HOURLY ON THE HOUR ONLY ARCHITECT LED-BUILDING TOURS. Tours set off on the hour. Booking not required. Please arrive 10-15 mins before tour time. No self led tours.

Tower Hamlets Town Hall is the new headquarters for the London Borough of Tower Hamlets Council, encompasses the restoration of the Grade II listed former Royal London Hospital building, and the addition of a new build extension.

name: Tower and Churchyard of St Mary's Hornsey
description: Grade II* listed tower with restored chapel remaining from Medieval parish church. Tour includes crypt, ringing chamber & main roof with excellent extensive views in all directions. Organised by Friends of Hornsey Church Tower.

name: Transforming Trash to Treasure: Upcycling Workshop
description: Angel Yard is a versatile and creative communal hub. Located within Snell's Park in Edmonton, it provides a place for people to develop and share their skills, whilst enriching the community and strengthening social bonds, as people from diverse backgrounds come together to collaborate and learn.
address: Angel Yard, 34 Snells Park, Edmonton, N18 2FD

name: Trinity Buoy Wharf/Container City
description:
Home to London's only lighthouse, fine stock buildings, examples of the innovative Container City buildings and SS Robin, the world’s only surviving complete
Victorian steamship. This former buoy manufacturing site is now a centre for the creative industries with various sculptures and installations.

name: Turf Projects (Whitgift Centre)
description: Founded in 2013 by Croydon locals, Turf Projects is Croydon’s homegrown artist space and the first entirely artist-run contemporary art space in the borough.
address: 46-47 Trinity Court, Whitgift Centre, Croydon, CR0 1UQ

name: Turning Earth Ceramics Highgate
description: Former indoor garden design workshop converted into an open-access ceramics studio.

name: Turning Earth Ceramics Leyton - E10
description: Ceramics centre for the Lee Valley, covering the entire top floor of an old hardware factory. Three rooms, providing just over 8000 sq ft of floor space; the main room is capped by its original saw-tooth glass roof feature.

name: Twickenham Museum
description: Grade II listed former waterman's cottage c1720. Restored and converted into a museum celebrating the rich history of Twickenham, Whitton, Teddington and the Hamptons.

name: UCL Pathology Museum
description: Based at the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead, the UCL Pathology Museum contains nearly 6,000 human pathology specimens relating to the study of disease and the history of medicine. Today, this important collection is used to facilitate teaching, research and public engagement in human health and disease, both at the museum and across University College London.
address: 2nd Floor, Medical School, Rowland Hill Street, NW3 2PF

name: University of East London - Architecture and Visual Art
description:
The University of East London’s Architecture and Visual Arts is a lively School that combines, Architecture, Physical Design and the Visual Arts. This perfect combination of creative programmes cross-pollinate, providing a fertile ground for creation, arts and design.
Our presence  will feature guided tours to the state-of-the-art facilities, creative studios, and ‘Way out East’ gallery.

name: Up in Smoke by John Booth X CAN
description: Up in Smoke - the NOW Gallery Design Commission by artist John Booth and architecture studio CAN, transforms the gallery into a vibrant installation that reveals the rich history of Greenwich Peninsula, through its iconic chimneys. The exhibition combines the duo's distinctive styles: Booth's playful, colourful design aesthetic and CAN's fresh, irreverent approach to architecture.

name: Vestry House Museum
description: Join architects Studio Weave and the Waltham Forest Culture team to go behind the scenes at the museum. The Grade II-listed building was constructed in 1730 to house the parish workhouse. After a variety of other uses it opened as Walthamstow Museum in 1931. The museum is currently closed for transformation into a fully accessible and inclusive museum, join a tour to hear about the plans.

name: Victoria Station Arcade
description: Victoria Station Arcade is an excellent example of Edwardian retail architecture. It has recently been refurbished with period details reinstated. Talks will occur every half-hour during the event.
address: Victoria Station Arcade, Terminus Place, SW1E 5ND

name: WAX Atelier within Abney Park
description: Once a Victorian arboretum, Abney Park Cemetery, part of London's Magnificent Seven, was revitalised with National Heritage Lottery funding in 2021. The renovation restored the chapel and main entrance, creating a vibrant workshop space for London-based art and design collective, WAX Atelier. During Open House, WAX Atelier will showcase innovative projects in their unique workspace amidst the park
address: Abney Park, 215 Stoke Newington High Street, N16 0LH

name: Walsingham Road
description: This four double-bedroom Victorian terraced home sits on a quiet, tree-lined residential street between Clapton and Stoke Newington. A comprehensive restoration and extension project by Partner London artfully balances the restored original features with natural, sympathetic materials and considered details to create a home well-suited to modern lifestyles within the original Victorian fabric.

name: Walthamstow Central library
description: A Grade II Listed building of special architectural and historic interest, it originated at the end of the 19th century, during which Walthamstow was transformed from a rural community to a bustling suburb of “London over the border".
address: Walthamstow Central library, High Street, E17 7JN

name: Walworth Garden
description: Our timber frame building was designed by Matrix Feminist Design Co-Operative, and built by women. It represents our community's history of activism - the same ethos that transformed our site from dereliction into a thriving community garden

name: Walworth Neighbourhood Food Tour
description: Based on the Walworth Neighbourhood Food Model, this walking tour includes visits to selected food and gardening initiatives in Walworth, introducing participants to existing challenges and opportunities in the local food system.

name: Walworth Town Hall
description: The Grade II listed Victorian complex, originally built between 1865 – 1906, is one of London’s most iconic civic buildings. After a devastating fire in 2013, it was placed in the Heritage at Risk Register and closed. Now, after sensitive restoration by Feix & Merlin and General Projects, it reopens its doors. With a modern CLT extension that celebrates its former glory while embracing its future.
address: Walworth Town Hall, 155 Walworth Road, SE17 1RS

name: Warehouse Art Collective
description:
In our House, creativity is a way of life. Warehouse Art Collective forges friendships and art under one roof. Artists who call this craftwork factory home have a lot in common, while exploring ideas and artistic visions with various materials and mediums.
The public can witness the artistic process and engage with contemporary art in the work/live industrial unit within Haringey Warehouse District.

name: Wax Chandlers' Hall
description: The sixth livery hall to be built on a site owned by the Company since 1501. The 1958 building stands on part of 1854 hall largely destroyed in WWII. East wall recently refaced. Completely refurbished and remodelled internally 2006/7.

name: Wennington Parish Church of St Mary and St Peter
description: Grade II listed Norman church dating from as early as 1190 and as late as 1248.

name: West Wickham Library
description: Art Deco building designed in 1934 by Leslie Kemp and Tasker in International Moderne style. Now the temporary home of West Wickham Library.

name: Westminster Abbey
description: UNESCO World Heritage site dating from 11C including stunning examples of Gothic and Medieval architecture and many hidden treasures.

name: Westminster Quaker Meeting House
description: Three centuries of Quakers in Westminster.  Opened in 1883, with front doors added in the 1920s. It was bomb-damaged in 1941 and rebuilt in 1956. Grade II listed registered place of worship, it contains a peaceful meeting room and 1950s wood panelling and fittings.

name: Wiener Holocaust Library
description:
The Wiener Holocaust Library is one of the world’s leading and most extensive archives on the Holocaust. Visit to view our latest exhibition 'Fred Kormis: Sculpting the Twentieth Century'. 

The building is a sensitive yet bold refurbishment of a historic Grade II listed townhouse including dramatic first floor reading room, mezzanine and ground floor exhibition spaces.

name: Wiggle Wonderland
description: Wiggle Wonderland is a touring pavilion activated by artists and communities. Created by architectural designer Beau McCarthy and artist Lucy Grainge, the pavilion is a timber-framed, open-air gallery. From hosting live performances to workshops, each install of the pavilion evolves and is shaped by people and place, and collaboration and co-creation are core to the project.
address: Croydon Urban Room, Units 161-162 & 1161-1162, Whitgift Centre

name: William Morris Society - Kelmscott House
description: Residence of Sir Francis Ronalds, George MacDonald and (from 1878-96) William Morris. Organised by William Morris Society. Access to The William Morris Society's premises in the Coach House and basement only, includes current exhibition.

name: Wood Green Creative Spaces and Places Tour
description: Join us for the Wood Green Creative Spaces and Places Tour, a journey through the workspaces of the creative industries of Wood Green. This tour offers a unique opportunity to visit a few of Wood Green’s workspaces showcasing a range of studios such as those for ceramics, music, visual arts, and design.
address: Outside the entrance to River Park House opposite Wood Green undergro

name: Wood Green Placemaking Walking Tour
description: A walking tour to see a number of co-designed projects completed by Haringey Council by working with Wood Green's local community. Including community parklets, two large murals, a new café, and the award winning Rising Green Youth Hub.
address: Roj Café, Ducketts Common Park, N8 0EP

name: Wrotham Park
description: A privately-owned Grade II listed Palladian mansion with grand interiors restored in 1883, set in 300 acres of parkland in the midst of 2,500 acres. Built for Admiral The Hon. John Byng.

name: Zaha Hadid Foundation
description: Explore parts of this Grade II listed former Victorian primary school, once the HQ of Zaha Hadid Architects and now home to the Zaha Hadid Foundation. A new exhibition 'Zaha Hadid: Paper Museums' will be open featuring original material of museum projects designed by Zaha Hadid Architects - entry is free. There will be free drop-in curator talks and model-making workshops.
address: Zaha Hadid Foundation, 10 Bowling Green Lane, EC1R 0BQ

name: Zoroastrian Centre For Europe (formerly Grosvenor Cinema)
description: Grade II* listed Art Deco building with well-preserved interior. Auditorium with deep coved ribs; proscenium arch flanked by fluted columns. Restoration fully funded by  donations from Zoroastrian faith community, without government grants.

name: thinkFOUND
description: thinkFOUND make socially and environmentally sustainable furniture. We represent a social value model that gives back to communities around London. From our workshop in the Argall Industrial Estate we incorporate carpentry, fabrication, upcycling, training, employment, coaching and more. Over the weekend we will be hosting an open studio demonstrating our processes and showcasing past work.
